question: Question_03_(b)
statement:
Let A be the matrix for the linear transformation T. Suppose we know
that $\mathbf{v}_1=\begin{bmatrix}1\\1\\1\end{bmatrix}$,
$\mathbf{v}_2=\begin{bmatrix}0\\1\\1\end{bmatrix}$,
$\mathbf{v}_3=\begin{bmatrix}1\\0\\1\end{bmatrix}$ are eigenvectors of A
associated to the eigenvalues $\lambda=1$, $\lambda=2$, and $\lambda=3$
respectively.

Calculate $T(\mathbf{e}_1)$.
sols:
The linear transformation acting on the vector $\mathbf{e}_1$ will get
given by

\[T(\mathbf{e}_1)=A\mathbf{e}_1.\]

From
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2012/Question_3_(a)}{part
(a)} we have that

\[\mathbf{e}_1=\mathbf{v}_1-\mathbf{v}_2.\]

In the question we are given the eigenvalues for these eigenvectors so
we know

\begin{align*}
A\mathbf{v}_1&=1\mathbf{v}_1\\
A\mathbf{v}_2&=2\mathbf{v}_2
\end{align*}

Therefore

\[T(\mathbf{e}_1)=A\mathbf{e}_1=A\mathbf{v}_1-A\mathbf{v}_2=\mathbf{v}_1-2\mathbf{v}_2=
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
-1\\
-1
\end{bmatrix}.\]
hints:
Since A is the matrix for the linear transformation then

\[T(\mathbf{e}_1)=A\mathbf{e}_1\]

How can our knowledge from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2012/Question_3_(a)}{part(a)}
along with the fact that $\mathbf{v}_1$, $\mathbf{v}_2$, $\mathbf{v}_3$
are eigenvectors help us?
